quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 3 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: 3.4: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) Theory
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Predicting molecular geometry from electron pairs

questions.question: What is the fundamental premise of VSEPR theory?
options: Electron pairs in the valence shell stay as far apart as possible to minimize repulsion
Protons in the nucleus repel each other to determine bond angles
Atoms in a molecule always attempt to form a perfect circle
Electrons are attracted to other electron pairs in neighboring atoms
questions.explanation: VSEPR stands for Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion; it posits that electron groups around a central atom will orient themselves to be at the maximum possible distance from one another.

questions.question: In VSEPR theory, what constitutes an 'electron group' or 'electron domain'?
options: A single bond, a double bond, a triple bond, or a lone pair
Only the electrons involved in single covalent bonds
The total number of protons and neutrons in the central atom
questions.explanation: For the purposes of predicting shape, any region of electron density—whether it contains one, two, or three pairs in a bond, or a single lone pair—counts as one electron group.

questions.question: Which type of electron group typically exerts the greatest repulsive force according to VSEPR theory?
questions.explanation: Lone pairs are held closer to the nucleus of a single atom and occupy more space than bonding pairs, leading to greater repulsion against neighboring groups.

questions.question: If a central atom is surrounded by 4 electron groups, what is its electron-group geometry?
questions.explanation: Four groups of electrons will move to the corners of a tetrahedron to achieve the maximum separation of $109.5^\circ$.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'electron-group geometry' and 'molecular geometry'?
options: Molecular geometry describes only the positions of atoms, while electron-group geometry includes lone pairs
They are always the same regardless of lone pairs
Electron-group geometry describes the nucleus, while molecular geometry describes the electrons
Molecular geometry is 2D, while electron-group geometry is 3D
questions.explanation: Electron-group geometry looks at where all electron domains are. Molecular geometry (or shape) only describes the relative positions of the atoms themselves.

questions.question: A molecule with 3 bonding groups and 0 lone pairs on the central atom has what molecular shape?
questions.explanation: With 3 groups and no lone pairs, the atoms stay in a single plane at $120^\circ$ angles from each other.

questions.question: What happens to the bond angles in a molecule when one or more lone pairs are present on the central atom?
options: The bond angles remain exactly the same as the ideal geometry
questions.explanation: Because lone pairs repel bonding pairs more strongly than bonding pairs repel each other, they 'push' the bonds closer together.

questions.question: How many electron groups are around the central carbon atom in $CO_2$?
questions.explanation: Carbon dioxide has two double bonds. Since each double bond counts as one electron group, there are two groups in total, leading to a linear shape.

questions.question: Which of the following geometries corresponds to having 5 electron groups?
questions.explanation: Five electron domains arrange themselves with three in an equatorial plane and two in axial positions to minimize repulsion.

questions.question: Which order of repulsive strength is correct according to VSEPR?
options: Lone pair-Lone pair > Lone pair-Bonding pair > Bonding pair-Bonding pair
Bonding pair-Bonding pair > Lone pair-Bonding pair > Lone pair-Lone pair
Lone pair-Bonding pair > Lone pair-Lone pair > Bonding pair-Bonding pair
All repulsions are equal in strength
questions.explanation: The repulsion between two lone pairs is the strongest, followed by a lone pair and a bond, with the repulsion between two bonds being the weakest.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered the spatial logic of VSEPR.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You have a solid understanding of electron repulsion.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember that lone pairs 'take up more space' than bonds.
scoreMessages.0: Practice identifying electron groups to better predict molecular shapes.
